StepReference.Description:
Authorization Code Reuse

PrOfESSOS validates the one-time use property of the Authorization Code, which is important if a code is exposed to untrusted parties. This may occur for a number of reasons such as through the Browser History, exposed server or request logs, or open redirectors.

Prerequisites

The OP supports the authorization_code_grant and PrOfESSOS test clients can make use of the code flow.

Execution

PrOfESSOS attempts to redeem an Authorization Code that has already been used by the same client.

Result Evaluation

The attack ist considered successful if a valid Token Response is returned.

Countermeasures

OpenID Connect Core 1.0, Section 3.1.2.7 requires the Authorization Response in the code flow to be validated according to RFC6749, Section 4.1, which states: If an authorization code is used more than once, the authorization server MUST deny the request and SHOULD revoke (when possible) all tokens previously issued based on that authorization code.
StepReference.Name: Authorization Code Reuse (Same Client)

StepReference.Description:
Redirect URI Validation

PrOfESSOS tests the validation of the redirect_uri parameter within the Authentication Request by including a redirect_uri value that is not registered for the submitted client_id. If an authorization code is returned to the malicious redirect URI, an Authorization Code Injection attack is simulated to test whether the code can be successfully exchanged for an Access or ID Token.

Execution

PrOfESSOS submits a redirect URI registered with a different client and, in case an Authorization Code is returned, attempts to redeem the code at the OP's token endpoint.

Prerequisites

The OP supports the authorization_code_grant and PrOfESSOS clients are allowed to use the code flow.

Result Evaluation

The attack is considered successful if an Authorization Code is returned to a redirect URI that has not been registered with the OP for the client used.

Countermeasures

OpenID Connect Core 1.0, Section 3.1.2.1 requires that the redirect_uri submitted in an Authentication Request MUST exactly match one of the Redirection URI values for the Client pre-registered at the OpenID Provider, with the matching performed as described in Section 6.2.1 of [RFC3986] (Simple String Comparison). For OAUTH, similar recommendations are proposed in the OAUTH 2.0 Security Best Current Practice (Draft), Section 4.1.3.
StepReference.Name: Redirect URI Validation (AR) - Other Client

StepReference.Description:
Redirect URI Validation

PrOfESSOS tests the validation of the redirect_uri parameter within the Authentication Request by including a redirect_uri value that is not registered for the submitted client_id. If an authorization code is returned to the malicious redirect URI, an Authorization Code Injection attack is simulated to test whether the code can be successfully exchanged for an Access or ID Token.

Execution

PrOfESSOS tests the validation of the redirect_uri parameter at the OP, probing for a HTTP Parameter Pollution weakness. The Authentication Request contains two redirect_uri parameters, the first one pointing towards the correct Redirect URI of the benign RP while the second redirect_uri parameter points to an attacker controlled endpoint. If different URL parsing mechanisms are employed during processing of the Authentication Request, the validation logic might choose and successfully validate the benign Redirecet URI while the actual response generating logic makes use of the malicious endpoint.

Prerequisites

The OP supports the authorization_code_grant and PrOfESSOS clients are allowed to use the code flow.

Result Evaluation

The attack is considered successful if an Authorization Code is returned to a redirect URI that has not been registered with the OP for the client used.

Countermeasures

OpenID Connect Core 1.0, Section 3.1.2.1 requires that the redirect_uri submitted in an Authentication Request MUST exactly match one of the Redirection URI values for the Client pre-registered at the OpenID Provider, with the matching performed as described in Section 6.2.1 of [RFC3986] (Simple String Comparison). For OAUTH, similar recommendations are proposed in the OAUTH 2.0 Security Best Current Practice (Draft), Section 4.1.3.
StepReference.Name: Redirect URI Validation (AR) - Parameter Pollution A

StepReference.Description:
Redirect URI Validation - Token Request

PrOfESSOS tests the validation of the redirect_uri parameter within the Token Request by including a redirect_uri value that differs from the redirect URI included in the prior Authentication Request.

Execution

PrOfESSOS issues a Token Request containing no redirect_uri parameter, even though one was present in the Authentication Request.

Prerequisites

The OP supports the authorization_code_grant and PrOfESSOS clients are allowed to use the code flow.

Result Evaluation

The attack is considered successful if a valid Token Response is returned from the token endpoint.

Countermeasures

OpenID Connect Core 1.0, Section 3.1.3.2 requires the OP to Ensure that the redirect_uri parameter value is identical to the redirect_uri parameter value that was included in the initial Authorization Request. If the redirect_uri parameter value is not present when there is only one registered redirect_uri value, the Authorization Server MAY return an error (since the Client should have included the parameter) or MAY proceed without an error (since OAuth 2.0 permits the parameter to be omitted in this case).
StepReference.Name: Redirect URI Validation (TR) - Exclude Redirect URI

If the redirect_uri parameter value is not present when there is only one registered redirect_uri value, the Authorization Server MAY return an error (since the Client should have included the parameter) or MAY proceed without an error (since OAuth 2.0 permits the parameter to be omitted in this case).
StepReference.Name: Redirect URI Validation (TR) - Append TLD

StepReference.Description:
Open Redirector

The OAUTH 2.0 specification, Section 4.2.2.1, defines an Error Response in for the Authorization Request, that is forwarded to the client using HTTP redirects to the URI provided in the redirect_uri parameter if the resource owner denies the access request or if the request fails for reasons other than a missing or invalid redirection URI. This may result in an Open Redirect Vulnerability at the OP, if arbitrary URIs can be registered for new clients. Besides abusing the open redirector for phishing attacks, this can be particularly problematic if the OP supports Dynamic Client Registration, applies pattern matching for redirect URIs and an RP is hosted in the same domain as the vulnerable OP (cf. Closing Open Redirectors, Section 2.2).

Execution

PrOfESSOS issues a token request containing invalid scope values.

Result Evaluation

The attack is considered successful if the Error Response is returned to the client without end user interaction.

Mitigation

The RFC draft OAuth 2.0 Security: Closing Open Redirectors in OAuth recommends to either respond with an HTTP 400 (Bad Request) status code error instead of returning the to the client's redirect URI or to make sure that potential referer headers are cleared, e.g., using intermediate redirects, Referer Policy or an appropriate Content Security Policy. Because OpenID Connect mandates exact string matching of the redirect URI, compliant implementations should not be vulnerable to the attack described in Section 2.2 of the RFC draft. However, the implicit trust of users into the Identity Provider makes this an attractive target for abuse, for example, in phishing attacks.
StepReference.Name: Open Redirector on the OP - Invalid Scope

StepReference.Description:
Authorization Code Substitution

PrOfESSOS simulates a Code Substitution attack aimed at what is commonly referred to as OAUTH Authentication. In this scenario, an attacker controlled malicious app receives a valid Authorization Code issued by a benign Identity Provider as result of a victim's authentication. Next, the attacker starts a login process within the target application, which uses the same benign Identity Provider, and, in the Authorization Response, substitutes the Authorization Code with the code that was leaked to the attacker by the malicious app.

Prerequisites

The OP supports the authorization_code_grant and PrOfESSOS test clients can make use of the code flow.

Execution

PrOfESSOS attempts to redeem an Authorization Code that was issued to a different client and has not yet been used in a Token Request.

Result Evaluation

The attack is considered successful if a valid Token Response is returned from the token endpoint.

Countermeasures

OAuth 2.0 Threat Model and Security Considerations requires clients to always include their client_id in Token Requests and Authorization Servers to validate that the presented code was indeed issued to the client. OpenID Connect, Section 3.1.3.1f mandates that confidential clients MUST authenticate and that the OP MUST authenticate the client if possible and Ensure the Authorization Code was issued to the authenticated Client.
StepReference.Name: Authorization Code Substitution

StepReference.Description:
Authorization Code Substitution

PrOfESSOS simulates a Code Substitution attack aimed at what is commonly referred to as OAUTH Authentication. In this scenario, an attacker controlled malicious app receives a valid Authorization Code issued by a benign Identity Provider as result of a victim's authentication. Next, the attacker starts a login process within the target application, which uses the same benign Identity Provider, and, in the Authorization Response, substitutes the Authorization Code with the code that was leaked to the attacker by the malicious app.

Execution

PrOfESSOS attempts to redeem an Authorization Code that was issued to a different client and has not yet been used in a Token Request. The request to the Token Endpoint is made without client authentication, neither the client_id nor any form of client credentials are submitted.

OpenID Connect, Section 3.1.3.1f mandates that confidential clients MUST authenticate and that the OP MUST authenticate the client if possible and Ensure the Authorization Code was issued to the authenticated Client.

StepReference.Description:
Client Authentication Validation

PrOfESSOS tests the validation of the client credentials at the Token Endpoint.

Prerequisites

The OP supports the authorization_code_grant and PrOfESSOS test clients can make use of the code flow.

Execution

PrOfESSOS attempts to redeem an authorization code using Basic Authentication with a randomly generated value as client_secret.

Result Evaluation

The attack is considered successful if a valid Token Response is returned.

Mitigation

According to OpenID Connect Core 1.0, Section 3.1.3.1, the OP MUST Authenticate the Client if it was issued Client Credentials or if it uses another Client Authentication method, per Section 9. Implementations must take special care not to introduce vulnerabilities in this important validation step.

StepReference.Description:
Client Authentication Validation

PrOfESSOS tests the validation of the client credentials at the Token Endpoint.

Prerequisites

The OP supports the authorization_code_grant, the Token Endpoint Authentication Method client_secret_jwt, and PrOfESSOS test clients can make use of the code flow.

Execution

PrOfESSOS tests the validation of the client_secret_jwt. In this test, the JWT header contains a mixed-case spelling of the Algorithm identifier none: "alg": "nONe" to circumvent naive blacklist. The JWT does not include a signature part.

Result Evaluation

The attack is considered successful if a valid Token Response is returned.

Mitigation

According to OpenID Connect Core 1.0, Section 3.1.3.1, the OP MUST Authenticate the Client if it was issued Client Credentials or if it uses another Client Authentication method, per Section 9. Implementations must take special care not to introduce vulnerabilities in this important validation step.
StepReference.Name: Client Authentication - Client-Secret-JWT, 'nONe' Algorithm 2

StepReference.Description:
Message Flow Downgrade to Implicit

PrOfESSOS tests if the OP can be downgraded to using less secure grant types that have not been registered.

Prerequisites

The OP supports, and test clients can use, the code flow.

Execution

The PrOfESSOS client is registered with grant_type=authorization_code. In the Authentication Request, an Implicit Flow is requested by using the parameter response_type=token id_token.

Result Evaluation

The attack is considered successful, if the Authorization Response contains at least one Token (ID Token, Access Token) in the URI Fragment.

Mitigation

Only grant types that have been assigned to the client during registration should return a valid Authorization Response. We recommend that OPs prevent clients from registering multiple flows with different security properties. The same client instance should not be able to register both authorization_code and implicit. Furthermore, draft-ietf-oauth-security-topics-12, Section 3.1.2, recommends that clients SHOULD NOT use the implicit grant [...], unless the issued access tokens are sender-constrained and access token injection in the authorization response is prevented.
StepReference.Name: Message Flow Confusion - Response Type

StepReference.Description:
Message Flow Confusion - Response Mode

PrOfESSOS tests if the OP can be made to use less secure response mode that is not allowed for the requested flow.

Prerequisites

The OP supports, and test clients can use or register, the implicit flow.

Execution

PrOfESSOS requests an id_token using the implicit flow and sets the response_mode parameter to query.

Result Evaluation

The attack is considered successful, if the Authorization Response contains at least one Token (ID Token, Access Token) in the query string of the URI (not in the fragment).

Mitigation

As per OAuth 2.0 Multiple Response Type Encoding Practices, Section 5, the OP must not include Access Tokens or ID Tokens in the URL query parameters.
StepReference.Name: Message Flow Confusion - Response Mode

StepReference.Description:
PKCE Validation

PrOfESSOS tests the validation of the PKCE code_verifier.

Prerequisites

The OP supports the code flow and PKCE.

Execution

A code_challenge is included in the Authentication Request. In the following Token Request, an invalid code_verifier value is submitted to the OP.

Result Evaluation

The attack is considered successful if a valid Token is returned in the Token Response.

Mitigation

The PKCE challenge and verifier must be properly validated by the OP according to RFC 7636. Also note that the draft-ietf-oauth-security-topics-12, Section 3.1.1, states that Clients utilizing the authorization grant type MUST use PKCE [RFC7636] [...] Note: although PKCE so far was recommended as a mechanism to protect native apps, this advice applies to all kinds of OAuth clients, including web applications.
StepReference.Name: PKCE 1 - TR: Invalid Verifier

StepReference.Description:
PKCE Validation

PrOfESSOS tests the validation of the PKCE code_verifier.

Prerequisites

The OP supports the code flow and PKCE.

Execution

A code_challenge_method=S256 parameter is included in the Authentication Request, indicating that 'SHA-256' is used to compute the code challenge. In the following Token Request, PrOfESSOS submits the original value of the code_challenge as code_verifier, as if using code_challenge_method=plain. In addition, an (invalid) parameter code_challenge_method=plain is added to the Token Request.

Result Evaluation

The attack is considered successful if a valid Token is returned in the Token Response.

Mitigation

The PKCE challenge and verifier must be properly validated by the OP according to RFC 7636. We further recommend OPs to not support the code_challenge_method=plain. Note, that the draft-ietf-oauth-security-topics-12, Section 3.1.1, states that Clients utilizing the authorization grant type MUST use PKCE [RFC7636] [...] Note: although PKCE so far was recommended as a mechanism to protect native apps, this advice applies to all kinds of OAuth clients, including web applications.
StepReference.Name: PKCE 4 - Downgrade to Plain

StepReference.Description:
Sub Claim Spoofing

PrOfESSOS tests the validation of the Authentication Request at the OP by embedding a claims request parameter in the Authentication Request.

Prerequisites

The OP supports OpenID Connect in the code flow or an implicit grant.

Execution

The requested ID Token claim contains the sub value of the victim and is marked as essential.

Result Evaluation

The attack is considered successful, if the returned ID Token contains the sub value of the victim.

Mitigation

As per Step 4 of https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-core-1_0.html#AuthRequestValidation the OP must not reply with an ID Token for a different user if id_token_hint or claims request parameters are used with values not matching the authenticated user.
StepReference.Name: Sub Claim Spoofing 1 (sub_victim)

StepReference.Description:
Sub Claim Spoofing

PrOfESSOS tests the validation of the Authentication Request at the OP by embedding a claims request parameter in the Authentication Request.

Prerequisites

The OP supports OpenID Connect in the code flow or an implicit grant.

Execution

PrOfESSOS tests the validation of the Authentication Request at the OP. To this end, a claimsrequest is embedded in the Authentication Requests that contains the sub claim value of the victim in the claimsrequest's values array.

Result Evaluation

The attack is considered successful, if the returned ID Token contains the sub value of the victim.

Mitigation

As per Step 4 of https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-core-1_0.html#AuthRequestValidation the OP must not reply with an ID Token for a different user if id_token_hint or claims request parameters are used with values not matching the authenticated user.

StepReference.Description:
Sub Claim Spoofing

PrOfESSOS tests the validation of the Authentication Request at the OP by embedding a claims request parameter in the Authentication Request.

Prerequisites

The OP supports OpenID Connect in the code flow or an implicit grant.

Execution

PrOfESSOS tests the validation of the Authentication Request at the OP. To this end, an id_token_hint is embedded in the attacker's Authentication Requests that contains a valid ID Token of the victim. The attack is successful, if the OP issues a new ID Token containing the victims identity.

Result Evaluation

The attack is considered successful, if the returned ID Token contains the sub value of the victim.

Mitigation

As per Step 4 of https://openid.net/specs/openid-connect-core-1_0.html#AuthRequestValidation the OP must not reply with an ID Token for a different user if id_token_hint or claims request parameters are used with values not matching the authenticated user.
